title: 109_s1909
content: The Medicare Telehealth Enhancement Act of 2005 expands access to telehealth services, increases types of originating sites, clarifies regulations, and allows for practitioners across state lines. It also includes a grant program through HRSA. Title I of the Medicare Telehealth Enhancement Act of 2005 focuses on expanding access to telehealth services by amending the Social Security Act to allow services without regard to geographic location. It also increases the number of types of originating sites and provides clarification on regulations. The Medicare Telehealth Enhancement Act of 2005 expands access to telehealth services by amending the Social Security Act to include additional originating sites such as skilled nursing facilities, renal dialysis facilities, and mental health clinics. The act also clarifies the term "originating site" for determining eligibility to receive a facility fee. The Medicare Telehealth Enhancement Act of 2005 expands access to telehealth services by including additional originating sites such as skilled nursing facilities, renal dialysis facilities, and mental health clinics. It clarifies the term "originating site" for eligibility to receive a facility fee without affecting the ability to submit claims for telehealth services provided to other sites with telehealth systems. SEC. 103 amends the Social Security Act to include store-and-forward technologies in telehealth programs. SEC. 104 expands the practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services. Section 1834(m) of the Social Security Act is amended to redefine the term 'practitioner' to include physical therapists, occupational therapists, and qualified speech-language pathologists. The term 'practitioner' in Section 1834(m) of the Social Security Act now includes physical therapists, occupational therapists, and qualified speech-language pathologists, along with certified providers and other individuals or entities determined appropriate by the Secretary. SEC. 105 expands covered telehealth services under the Social Security Act to include professional services and any additional services specified by the Secretary. SEC. 106 aims to facilitate the provision of telehealth services across state lines. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will work with stakeholders to promote multistate practitioner licensure for telehealth services under Medicare across state lines. The terms "telehealth service," "physician," and "practitioner" are defined in the Social Security Act. The term "medicare program" refers to the health insurance program administered by the Secretary of Health and Human Services under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. SEC. 107. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by sections 101 through 105 shall apply to services furnished on or after the date that is 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act. TITLE II--HRSA GRANT PROGRAM SEC. 201. GRANT PROGRAM FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF TELEHEALTH NETWORKS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will make grants to eligible entities to expand access to healthcare services in rural, frontier, and urban medically underserved areas through telehealth. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive a grant. The Secretary may require information for grant applications, including anticipated need, activities description, project continuation plan, meeting healthcare needs of rural populations, and community involvement in network development and operations. The application for grants must show the integration of telehealth in the community to avoid technology redundancy and achieve economies of scale. Eligible entities include hospitals or health care providers in a network of community-based providers with specific requirements. Entities eligible for grants must demonstrate the use of telehealth for education or economic development as required by the Secretary. Eligible organizations include community or migrant health centers, local health departments, nonprofit hospitals, private practice health professionals, publicly funded health or social services agencies, skilled nursing facilities, and publicly funded mental health facilities. Entities eligible for grants include public schools, libraries, universities, local government entities, local health entities, health-related nonprofit foundations, and academic health centers. For-profit entities may be included as long as the grant recipient is a not-for-profit entity. The Secretary will prioritize financial assistance based on established procedures. The Secretary will prioritize financial assistance for health care providers in underserved areas and those proposing telehealth systems linking rural hospitals. The applicant will use the provided amounts for health care applications and efficiency promotion. They must demonstrate project viability through cost participation and show support from financial, institutional, and community sources. A detailed plan for coordinating system use by eligible entities is required to prioritize health care services over non-clinical uses. The Secretary will establish the terms, conditions, and maximum grant amount for individual recipients annually. The Secretary will establish terms and conditions for grants under this section annually. Recipients can use the grant for telehealth equipment and facility improvements, including computer hardware, software, and technical assistance. The grant under this section can be used for technical assistance, instructional programming, demonstration projects for medical training, telenursing services, promoting patient adherence to guidelines for chronic diseases, and covering transmission costs and equipment maintenance. The grant under this section can be used for various purposes, including compensation for specialists and health care providers, telehealth projects, electronic archival of patient records, and collection of usage statistics. Prohibited uses include acquiring real property and excessive equipment purchases. Expenditures for transmission equipment, construction, and indirect costs must not exceed specified percentages of the total grant funds. The Secretary will ensure no duplication of telehealth networks and coordinate with other agencies. The Secretary will coordinate with other agencies to pool resources for funding meritorious proposals and carry out outreach activities to advise potential end users in rural and medically underserved areas about the grant program. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006, with additional funding for fiscal years 2007 through 2012. The Secretary will promptly implement the grant program. SEC. 202. REAUTHORIZATION OF TELEHEALTH NETWORK AND TELEHEALTH RESOURCE CENTERS GRANT PROGRAMS. Amends subsection (s) of section 330I of the Public Health Service Act to allocate $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2007 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2008 through 2012 to the grant programs.
